trial_identification.studytitle: A comparative study assessing the efficacy and acceptability of anorectal swabs for antenatal Group B Streptococcus (GBS) screening
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Low vaginal swabs versus Anorectal swabs for antenatal screening for Group B Streptococcus in Australian women at 35 to 37 weeks gestation, assessing the detection rate and pain/acceptability scores of the two swabs.

conditions.healthcondition: Group B Streptococcal (GBS) colonisation in pregnant women

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Studies of infection and infectious agents

interventions.interventions: Anorectal swab (ARS) for GBS, taken once only at 35-37 weeks gestation, immediately after taking the Low vagina swab (at the same session). All women undergo both the anorectal swab and low vaginal swab.
interventions.comparator: Low vaginal swab (LVS) for GBS, taken once only at 35-37 weeks gestation, immediately before taking the Anorectal swab (at the same session)

primaryOutcome.outcome: Pain score for collection of the swabs, on a 5 point Likert scale (Pain-free, Minor discomfort, Moderate pain, Very painful, Unbearable)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At the time of collecting the swabs

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Acceptability for collection of the swabs, on a 5 point Likert scale (Totally acceptable, Somewhat acceptable, Acceptable, Not acceptable, Not at all acceptable)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At the time of collecting the swabs

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Positivity rate of the LVS and ARS for GBS. The swabs are analysed by microbiological culture in an approved and accredited microbiological laboratory, and the results are reported electronically as either positive or negative for GBS.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At the time of collecting the swabs

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Pregnant women at 35-37 weeks gestation Planning vaginal delivery

trial_design.concealment: Women who are planning for a vaginal delivery are enrolled into the study at 35-37 weeks gestation. All subjects undergo the same intervention (LVS and ARS), and therefore there is no allocation of treatment or concealment procedures.
trial_design.sequence: No randomisation is required, as all subjects undergo the same intervention (LVS and ARS)

fundingsource.fundingaddress: College House 254 - 260 Albert St East Melbourne Victoria 3002

secondarysponsor.sponsoraddress: Royal Hospital For Women Barker Street Randwick NSW 2031

ethicsAndSummary.summary: For antenatal screening for Group B Streptococcus (GBS), current guidelines from the Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists (RANZCOG) recommend both a low vaginal swab (LVS) and an anorectal swab (ARS) to be taken. The addition of an ARS to a LVS is reported to increase the GBS detection rate compared to performing a LVS alone. Despite these recommendations, many clinicians perform a LVS alone for GBS screening, and patient and physician acceptability may be responsible. We aim to assess the pain and acceptability of the LVS and ARS, and the detection rate for GBS from each swab.
